speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: ACT I

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: SCENE I. A hall in DUKE SOLINUS'S palace.

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: Enter DUKE SOLINUS, AEGEON, Gaoler, Officers, and other Attendants

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: Proceed, Solinus, to procure my fall

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: And by the doom of death end woes and all.

speaker: DUKE SOLINUS
text_entry: Merchant of Syracuse, plead no more;

speaker: DUKE SOLINUS
text_entry: I am not partial to infringe our laws:

speaker: DUKE SOLINUS
text_entry: The enmity and discord which of late

speaker: DUKE SOLINUS
text_entry: Sprung from the rancorous outrage of your duke

speaker: DUKE SOLINUS
text_entry: To merchants, our well-dealing countrymen,

speaker: DUKE SOLINUS
text_entry: Who wanting guilders to redeem their lives

speaker: DUKE SOLINUS
text_entry: Have seal'd his rigorous statutes with their bloods,

speaker: DUKE SOLINUS
text_entry: Excludes all pity from our threatening looks.

speaker: DUKE SOLINUS
text_entry: For, since the mortal and intestine jars

speaker: DUKE SOLINUS
text_entry: 'Twixt thy seditious countrymen and us,

speaker: DUKE SOLINUS
text_entry: It hath in solemn synods been decreed

speaker: DUKE SOLINUS
text_entry: Both by the Syracusians and ourselves,

speaker: DUKE SOLINUS
text_entry: To admit no traffic to our adverse towns Nay, more,

speaker: DUKE SOLINUS
text_entry: If any born at Ephesus be seen

speaker: DUKE SOLINUS
text_entry: At any Syracusian marts and fairs;

speaker: DUKE SOLINUS
text_entry: Again: if any Syracusian born

speaker: DUKE SOLINUS
text_entry: Come to the bay of Ephesus, he dies,

speaker: DUKE SOLINUS
text_entry: His goods confiscate to the duke's dispose,

speaker: DUKE SOLINUS
text_entry: Unless a thousand marks be levied,

speaker: DUKE SOLINUS
text_entry: To quit the penalty and to ransom him.

speaker: DUKE SOLINUS
text_entry: Thy substance, valued at the highest rate,

speaker: DUKE SOLINUS
text_entry: Cannot amount unto a hundred marks;

speaker: DUKE SOLINUS
text_entry: Therefore by law thou art condemned to die.

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: Yet this my comfort: when your words are done,

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: My woes end likewise with the evening sun.

speaker: DUKE SOLINUS
text_entry: Well, Syracusian, say in brief the cause

speaker: DUKE SOLINUS
text_entry: Why thou departed'st from thy native home

speaker: DUKE SOLINUS
text_entry: And for what cause thou camest to Ephesus.

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: A heavier task could not have been imposed

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: Than I to speak my griefs unspeakable:

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: Yet, that the world may witness that my end

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: Was wrought by nature, not by vile offence,

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: I'll utter what my sorrows give me leave.

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: In Syracusa was I born, and wed

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: Unto a woman, happy but for me,

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: And by me, had not our hap been bad.

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: With her I lived in joy; our wealth increased

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: By prosperous voyages I often made

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: To Epidamnum; till my factor's death

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: And the great care of goods at random left

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: Drew me from kind embracements of my spouse:

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: From whom my absence was not six months old

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: Before herself, almost at fainting under

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: The pleasing punishment that women bear,

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: Had made provision for her following me

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: And soon and safe arrived where I was.

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: There had she not been long, but she became

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: A joyful mother of two goodly sons;

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: And, which was strange, the one so like the other,

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: As could not be distinguish'd but by names.

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: That very hour, and in the self-same inn,

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: A meaner woman was delivered

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: Of such a burden, male twins, both alike:

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: Those,--for their parents were exceeding poor,--

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: I bought and brought up to attend my sons.

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: My wife, not meanly proud of two such boys,

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: Made daily motions for our home return:

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: Unwilling I agreed. Alas! too soon,

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: We came aboard.

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: A league from Epidamnum had we sail'd,

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: Before the always wind-obeying deep

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: Gave any tragic instance of our harm:

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: But longer did we not retain much hope;

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: For what obscured light the heavens did grant

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: Did but convey unto our fearful minds

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: A doubtful warrant of immediate death;

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: Which though myself would gladly have embraced,

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: Yet the incessant weepings of my wife,

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: Weeping before for what she saw must come,

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: And piteous plainings of the pretty babes,

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: That mourn'd for fashion, ignorant what to fear,

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: Forced me to seek delays for them and me.

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: And this it was, for other means was none:

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: The sailors sought for safety by our boat,

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: And left the ship, then sinking-ripe, to us:

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: My wife, more careful for the latter-born,

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: Had fasten'd him unto a small spare mast,

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: Such as seafaring men provide for storms;

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: To him one of the other twins was bound,

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: Whilst I had been like heedful of the other:

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: The children thus disposed, my wife and I,

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: Fixing our eyes on whom our care was fix'd,

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: Fasten'd ourselves at either end the mast;

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: And floating straight, obedient to the stream,

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: Was carried towards Corinth, as we thought.

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: At length the sun, gazing upon the earth,

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: Dispersed those vapours that offended us;

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: And by the benefit of his wished light,

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: The seas wax'd calm, and we discovered

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: Two ships from far making amain to us,

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: Of Corinth that, of Epidaurus this:

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: But ere they came,--O, let me say no more!

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: Gather the sequel by that went before.

speaker: DUKE SOLINUS
text_entry: Nay, forward, old man; do not break off so;

speaker: DUKE SOLINUS
text_entry: For we may pity, though not pardon thee.

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: O, had the gods done so, I had not now

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: Worthily term'd them merciless to us!

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: For, ere the ships could meet by twice five leagues,

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: We were encounterd by a mighty rock;

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: Which being violently borne upon,

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: Our helpful ship was splitted in the midst;

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: So that, in this unjust divorce of us,

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: Fortune had left to both of us alike

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: What to delight in, what to sorrow for.

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: Her part, poor soul! seeming as burdened

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: With lesser weight but not with lesser woe,

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: Was carried with more speed before the wind;

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: And in our sight they three were taken up

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: By fishermen of Corinth, as we thought.

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: At length, another ship had seized on us;

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: And, knowing whom it was their hap to save,

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: Gave healthful welcome to their shipwreck'd guests;

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: And would have reft the fishers of their prey,

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: Had not their bark been very slow of sail;

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: And therefore homeward did they bend their course.

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: Thus have you heard me sever'd from my bliss;

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: That by misfortunes was my life prolong'd,

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: To tell sad stories of my own mishaps.

speaker: DUKE SOLINUS
text_entry: And for the sake of them thou sorrowest for,

speaker: DUKE SOLINUS
text_entry: Do me the favour to dilate at full

speaker: DUKE SOLINUS
text_entry: What hath befall'n of them and thee till now.

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: My youngest boy, and yet my eldest care,

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: At eighteen years became inquisitive

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: After his brother: and importuned me

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: That his attendant--so his case was like,

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: Reft of his brother, but retain'd his name--

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: Might bear him company in the quest of him:

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: Whom whilst I labour'd of a love to see,

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: I hazarded the loss of whom I loved.

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: Five summers have I spent in furthest Greece,

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: Roaming clean through the bounds of Asia,

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: And, coasting homeward, came to Ephesus;

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: Hopeless to find, yet loath to leave unsought

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: Or that or any place that harbours men.

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: But here must end the story of my life;

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: And happy were I in my timely death,

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: Could all my travels warrant me they live.

speaker: DUKE SOLINUS
text_entry: Hapless AEgeon, whom the fates have mark'd

speaker: DUKE SOLINUS
text_entry: To bear the extremity of dire mishap!

speaker: DUKE SOLINUS
text_entry: Now, trust me, were it not against our laws,

speaker: DUKE SOLINUS
text_entry: Against my crown, my oath, my dignity,

speaker: DUKE SOLINUS
text_entry: Which princes, would they, may not disannul,

speaker: DUKE SOLINUS
text_entry: My soul would sue as advocate for thee.

speaker: DUKE SOLINUS
text_entry: But, though thou art adjudged to the death

speaker: DUKE SOLINUS
text_entry: And passed sentence may not be recall'd

speaker: DUKE SOLINUS
text_entry: But to our honour's great disparagement,

speaker: DUKE SOLINUS
text_entry: Yet I will favour thee in what I can.

speaker: DUKE SOLINUS
text_entry: Therefore, merchant, I'll limit thee this day

speaker: DUKE SOLINUS
text_entry: To seek thy life by beneficial help:

speaker: DUKE SOLINUS
text_entry: Try all the friends thou hast in Ephesus;

speaker: DUKE SOLINUS
text_entry: Beg thou, or borrow, to make up the sum,

speaker: DUKE SOLINUS
text_entry: And live; if no, then thou art doom'd to die.

speaker: DUKE SOLINUS
text_entry: Gaoler, take him to thy custody.

speaker: Gaoler
text_entry: I will, my lord.

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: Hopeless and helpless doth AEgeon wend,

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: But to procrastinate his lifeless end.

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: SCENE II. The Mart.

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: Enter ANTIPHOLUS of Syracuse, DROMIO of Syracuse, and First Merchant

speaker: First Merchant
text_entry: Therefore give out you are of Epidamnum,

speaker: First Merchant
text_entry: Lest that your goods too soon be confiscate.

speaker: First Merchant
text_entry: This very day a Syracusian merchant

speaker: First Merchant
text_entry: Is apprehended for arrival here;

speaker: First Merchant
text_entry: And not being able to buy out his life

speaker: First Merchant
text_entry: According to the statute of the town,

speaker: First Merchant
text_entry: Dies ere the weary sun set in the west.

speaker: First Merchant
text_entry: There is your money that I had to keep.

speaker: First Merchant
text_entry: ANTIPHOLUS

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Go bear it to the Centaur, where we host,

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: And stay there, Dromio, till I come to thee.

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Within this hour it will be dinner-time:

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Till that, I'll view the manners of the town,

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Peruse the traders, gaze upon the buildings,

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: And then return and sleep within mine inn,

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: For with long travel I am stiff and weary.

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Get thee away.

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Many a man would take you at your word,

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: And go indeed, having so good a mean.

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Exit

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: ANTIPHOLUS

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: A trusty villain, sir, that very oft,

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: When I am dull with care and melancholy,

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Lightens my humour with his merry jests.

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: What, will you walk with me about the town,

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: And then go to my inn and dine with me?

speaker: First Merchant
text_entry: I am invited, sir, to certain merchants,

speaker: First Merchant
text_entry: Of whom I hope to make much benefit;

speaker: First Merchant
text_entry: I crave your pardon. Soon at five o'clock,

speaker: First Merchant
text_entry: Please you, I'll meet with you upon the mart

speaker: First Merchant
text_entry: And afterward consort you till bed-time:

speaker: First Merchant
text_entry: My present business calls me from you now.

speaker: First Merchant
text_entry: ANTIPHOLUS

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Farewell till then: I will go lose myself

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: And wander up and down to view the city.

speaker: First Merchant
text_entry: Sir, I commend you to your own content.

speaker: First Merchant
text_entry: Exit

speaker: First Merchant
text_entry: ANTIPHOLUS

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: He that commends me to mine own content

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Commends me to the thing I cannot get.

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: I to the world am like a drop of water

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: That in the ocean seeks another drop,

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Who, falling there to find his fellow forth,

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Unseen, inquisitive, confounds himself:

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: So I, to find a mother and a brother,

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: In quest of them, unhappy, lose myself.

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Enter DROMIO of Ephesus

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Here comes the almanac of my true date.

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: What now? how chance thou art return'd so soon?

speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
text_entry: Return'd so soon! rather approach'd too late:

speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
text_entry: The capon burns, the pig falls from the spit,

speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
text_entry: The clock hath strucken twelve upon the bell;

speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
text_entry: My mistress made it one upon my cheek:

speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
text_entry: She is so hot because the meat is cold;

speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
text_entry: The meat is cold because you come not home;

speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
text_entry: You come not home because you have no stomach;

speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
text_entry: You have no stomach having broke your fast;

speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
text_entry: But we that know what 'tis to fast and pray

speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
text_entry: Are penitent for your default to-day.

speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
text_entry: ANTIPHOLUS

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Stop in your wind, sir: tell me this, I pray:

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Where have you left the money that I gave you?

speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
text_entry: O,--sixpence, that I had o' Wednesday last

speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
text_entry: To pay the saddler for my mistress' crupper?

speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
text_entry: The saddler had it, sir; I kept it not.

speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
text_entry: ANTIPHOLUS

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: I am not in a sportive humour now:

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Tell me, and dally not, where is the money?

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: We being strangers here, how darest thou trust

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: So great a charge from thine own custody?

speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
text_entry: I pray you, air, as you sit at dinner:

speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
text_entry: I from my mistress come to you in post;

speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
text_entry: If I return, I shall be post indeed,

speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
text_entry: For she will score your fault upon my pate.

speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
text_entry: Methinks your maw, like mine, should be your clock,

speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
text_entry: And strike you home without a messenger.

speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
text_entry: ANTIPHOLUS

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Come, Dromio, come, these jests are out of season;

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Reserve them till a merrier hour than this.

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Where is the gold I gave in charge to thee?

speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
text_entry: To me, sir? why, you gave no gold to me.

speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
text_entry: ANTIPHOLUS

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Come on, sir knave, have done your foolishness,

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: And tell me how thou hast disposed thy charge.

speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
text_entry: My charge was but to fetch you from the mart

speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
text_entry: Home to your house, the Phoenix, sir, to dinner:

speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
text_entry: My mistress and her sister stays for you.

speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
text_entry: ANTIPHOLUS

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: In what safe place you have bestow'd my money,

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Or I shall break that merry sconce of yours

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: That stands on tricks when I am undisposed:

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Where is the thousand marks thou hadst of me?

speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
text_entry: I have some marks of yours upon my pate,

speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
text_entry: Some of my mistress' marks upon my shoulders,

speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
text_entry: But not a thousand marks between you both.

speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
text_entry: If I should pay your worship those again,

speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
text_entry: Perchance you will not bear them patiently.

speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
text_entry: ANTIPHOLUS

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Thy mistress' marks? what mistress, slave, hast thou?

speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
text_entry: Your worship's wife, my mistress at the Phoenix;

speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
text_entry: She that doth fast till you come home to dinner,

speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
text_entry: And prays that you will hie you home to dinner.

speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
text_entry: ANTIPHOLUS

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: What, wilt thou flout me thus unto my face,

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Being forbid? There, take you that, sir knave.

speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
text_entry: What mean you, sir? for God's sake, hold your hands!

speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
text_entry: Nay, and you will not, sir, I'll take my heels.

speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
text_entry: Exit

speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
text_entry: ANTIPHOLUS

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Upon my life, by some device or other

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: The villain is o'er-raught of all my money.

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: They say this town is full of cozenage,

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: As, nimble jugglers that deceive the eye,

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Dark-working sorcerers that change the mind,

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Soul-killing witches that deform the body,

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Disguised cheaters, prating mountebanks,

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: And many such-like liberties of sin:

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: If it prove so, I will be gone the sooner.

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: I'll to the Centaur, to go seek this slave:

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: I greatly fear my money is not safe.

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Exit

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: ACT II

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: SCENE I. The house of ANTIPHOLUS of Ephesus.

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Enter ADRIANA and LUCIANA

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: Neither my husband nor the slave return'd,

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: That in such haste I sent to seek his master!

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: Sure, Luciana, it is two o'clock.

speaker: LUCIANA
text_entry: Perhaps some merchant hath invited him,

speaker: LUCIANA
text_entry: And from the mart he's somewhere gone to dinner.

speaker: LUCIANA
text_entry: Good sister, let us dine and never fret:

speaker: LUCIANA
text_entry: A man is master of his liberty:

speaker: LUCIANA
text_entry: Time is their master, and, when they see time,

speaker: LUCIANA
text_entry: They'll go or come: if so, be patient, sister.

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: Why should their liberty than ours be more?

speaker: LUCIANA
text_entry: Because their business still lies out o' door.

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: Look, when I serve him so, he takes it ill.

speaker: LUCIANA
text_entry: O, know he is the bridle of your will.

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: There's none but asses will be bridled so.

speaker: LUCIANA
text_entry: Why, headstrong liberty is lash'd with woe.

speaker: LUCIANA
text_entry: There's nothing situate under heaven's eye

speaker: LUCIANA
text_entry: But hath his bound, in earth, in sea, in sky:

speaker: LUCIANA
text_entry: The beasts, the fishes, and the winged fowls,

speaker: LUCIANA
text_entry: Are their males' subjects and at their controls:

speaker: LUCIANA
text_entry: Men, more divine, the masters of all these,

speaker: LUCIANA
text_entry: Lords of the wide world and wild watery seas,

speaker: LUCIANA
text_entry: Indued with intellectual sense and souls,

speaker: LUCIANA
text_entry: Of more preeminence than fish and fowls,

speaker: LUCIANA
text_entry: Are masters to their females, and their lords:

speaker: LUCIANA
text_entry: Then let your will attend on their accords.

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: This servitude makes you to keep unwed.

speaker: LUCIANA
text_entry: Not this, but troubles of the marriage-bed.

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: But, were you wedded, you would bear some sway.

speaker: LUCIANA
text_entry: Ere I learn love, I'll practise to obey.

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: How if your husband start some other where?

speaker: LUCIANA
text_entry: Till he come home again, I would forbear.

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: Patience unmoved! no marvel though she pause;

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: They can be meek that have no other cause.

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: A wretched soul, bruised with adversity,

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: We bid be quiet when we hear it cry;

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: But were we burdened with like weight of pain,

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: As much or more would we ourselves complain:

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: So thou, that hast no unkind mate to grieve thee,

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: With urging helpless patience wouldst relieve me,

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: But, if thou live to see like right bereft,

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: This fool-begg'd patience in thee will be left.

speaker: LUCIANA
text_entry: Well, I will marry one day, but to try.

speaker: LUCIANA
text_entry: Here comes your man; now is your husband nigh.

speaker: LUCIANA
text_entry: Enter DROMIO of Ephesus

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: Say, is your tardy master now at hand?

speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
text_entry: Nay, he's at two hands with me, and that my two ears

speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
text_entry: can witness.

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: Say, didst thou speak with him? know'st thou his mind?

speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
text_entry: Ay, ay, he told his mind upon mine ear:

speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
text_entry: Beshrew his hand, I scarce could understand it.

speaker: LUCIANA
text_entry: Spake he so doubtfully, thou couldst not feel his meaning?

speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
text_entry: Nay, he struck so plainly, I could too well feel his

speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
text_entry: blows; and withal so doubtfully that I could scarce

speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
text_entry: understand them.

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: But say, I prithee, is he coming home? It seems he

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: hath great care to please his wife.

speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
text_entry: Why, mistress, sure my master is horn-mad.

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: Horn-mad, thou villain!

speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
text_entry: I mean not cuckold-mad;

speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
text_entry: But, sure, he is stark mad.

speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
text_entry: When I desired him to come home to dinner,

speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
text_entry: He ask'd me for a thousand marks in gold:

speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
text_entry: ''Tis dinner-time,' quoth I; 'My gold!' quoth he;

speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
text_entry: 'Your meat doth burn,' quoth I; 'My gold!' quoth he:

speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
text_entry: 'Will you come home?' quoth I; 'My gold!' quoth he.

speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
text_entry: 'Where is the thousand marks I gave thee, villain?'

speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
text_entry: 'The pig,' quoth I, 'is burn'd;' 'My gold!' quoth he:

speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
text_entry: 'My mistress, sir' quoth I; 'Hang up thy mistress!

speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
text_entry: I know not thy mistress; out on thy mistress!'

speaker: LUCIANA
text_entry: Quoth who?

speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
text_entry: Quoth my master:

speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
text_entry: 'I know,' quoth he, 'no house, no wife, no mistress.'

speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
text_entry: So that my errand, due unto my tongue,

speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
text_entry: I thank him, I bare home upon my shoulders;

speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
text_entry: For, in conclusion, he did beat me there.

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: Go back again, thou slave, and fetch him home.

speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
text_entry: Go back again, and be new beaten home?

speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
text_entry: For God's sake, send some other messenger.

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: Back, slave, or I will break thy pate across.

speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
text_entry: And he will bless that cross with other beating:

speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
text_entry: Between you I shall have a holy head.

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: Hence, prating peasant! fetch thy master home.

speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
text_entry: Am I so round with you as you with me,

speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
text_entry: That like a football you do spurn me thus?

speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
text_entry: You spurn me hence, and he will spurn me hither:

speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
text_entry: If I last in this service, you must case me in leather.

speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
text_entry: Exit

speaker: LUCIANA
text_entry: Fie, how impatience loureth in your face!

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: His company must do his minions grace,

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: Whilst I at home starve for a merry look.

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: Hath homely age the alluring beauty took

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: From my poor cheek? then he hath wasted it:

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: Are my discourses dull? barren my wit?

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: If voluble and sharp discourse be marr'd,

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: Unkindness blunts it more than marble hard:

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: Do their gay vestments his affections bait?

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: That's not my fault: he's master of my state:

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: What ruins are in me that can be found,

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: By him not ruin'd? then is he the ground

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: Of my defeatures. My decayed fair

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: A sunny look of his would soon repair

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: But, too unruly deer, he breaks the pale

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: And feeds from home; poor I am but his stale.

speaker: LUCIANA
text_entry: Self-harming jealousy! fie, beat it hence!

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: Unfeeling fools can with such wrongs dispense.

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: I know his eye doth homage otherwhere,

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: Or else what lets it but he would be here?

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: Sister, you know he promised me a chain;

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: Would that alone, alone he would detain,

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: So he would keep fair quarter with his bed!

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: I see the jewel best enamelled

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: Will lose his beauty; yet the gold bides still,

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: That others touch, and often touching will

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: Wear gold: and no man that hath a name,

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: By falsehood and corruption doth it shame.

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: Since that my beauty cannot please his eye,

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: I'll weep what's left away, and weeping die.

speaker: LUCIANA
text_entry: How many fond fools serve mad jealousy!

speaker: LUCIANA
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: LUCIANA
text_entry: SCENE II. A public place.

speaker: LUCIANA
text_entry: Enter ANTIPHOLUS of Syracuse

speaker: LUCIANA
text_entry: ANTIPHOLUS

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: The gold I gave to Dromio is laid up

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Safe at the Centaur; and the heedful slave

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Is wander'd forth, in care to seek me out

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: By computation and mine host's report.

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: I could not speak with Dromio since at first

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: I sent him from the mart. See, here he comes.

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Enter DROMIO of Syracuse

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: How now sir! is your merry humour alter'd?

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: As you love strokes, so jest with me again.

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: You know no Centaur? you received no gold?

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Your mistress sent to have me home to dinner?

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: My house was at the Phoenix? Wast thou mad,

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: That thus so madly thou didst answer me?

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: What answer, sir? when spake I such a word?

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: ANTIPHOLUS

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Even now, even here, not half an hour since.

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: I did not see you since you sent me hence,

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Home to the Centaur, with the gold you gave me.

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: ANTIPHOLUS

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Villain, thou didst deny the gold's receipt,

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: And told'st me of a mistress and a dinner;

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: For which, I hope, thou felt'st I was displeased.

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: I am glad to see you in this merry vein:

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: What means this jest? I pray you, master, tell me.

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: ANTIPHOLUS

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Yea, dost thou jeer and flout me in the teeth?

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Think'st thou I jest? Hold, take thou that, and that.

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Beating him

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Hold, sir, for God's sake! now your jest is earnest:

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Upon what bargain do you give it me?

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: ANTIPHOLUS

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Because that I familiarly sometimes

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Do use you for my fool and chat with you,

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Your sauciness will jest upon my love

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: And make a common of my serious hours.

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: When the sun shines let foolish gnats make sport,

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: But creep in crannies when he hides his beams.

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: If you will jest with me, know my aspect,

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: And fashion your demeanor to my looks,

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Or I will beat this method in your sconce.

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Sconce call you it? so you would leave battering, I

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: had rather have it a head: an you use these blows

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: long, I must get a sconce for my head and ensconce

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: it too; or else I shall seek my wit in my shoulders.

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: But, I pray, sir why am I beaten?

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: ANTIPHOLUS

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Dost thou not know?

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Nothing, sir, but that I am beaten.

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: ANTIPHOLUS

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Shall I tell you why?

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Ay, sir, and wherefore; for they say every why hath

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: a wherefore.

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: ANTIPHOLUS

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Why, first,--for flouting me; and then, wherefore--

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: For urging it the second time to me.

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Was there ever any man thus beaten out of season,

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: When in the why and the wherefore is neither rhyme

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: nor reason?

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Well, sir, I thank you.

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: ANTIPHOLUS

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Thank me, sir, for what?

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Marry, sir, for this something that you gave me for nothing.

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: ANTIPHOLUS

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: I'll make you amends next, to give you nothing for

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: something. But say, sir, is it dinner-time?

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: No, sir; I think the meat wants that I have.

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: ANTIPHOLUS

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: In good time, sir; what's that?

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Basting.

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: ANTIPHOLUS

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Well, sir, then 'twill be dry.

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: If it be, sir, I pray you, eat none of it.

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: ANTIPHOLUS

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Your reason?

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Lest it make you choleric and purchase me another

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: dry basting.

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: ANTIPHOLUS

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Well, sir, learn to jest in good time: there's a

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: time for all things.

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: I durst have denied that, before you were so choleric.

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: ANTIPHOLUS

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: By what rule, sir?

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Marry, sir, by a rule as plain as the plain bald

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: pate of father Time himself.

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: ANTIPHOLUS

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Let's hear it.

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: There's no time for a man to recover his hair that

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: grows bald by nature.

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: ANTIPHOLUS

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: May he not do it by fine and recovery?

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Yes, to pay a fine for a periwig and recover the

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: lost hair of another man.

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: ANTIPHOLUS

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Why is Time such a niggard of hair, being, as it is,

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: so plentiful an excrement?

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Because it is a blessing that he bestows on beasts;

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: and what he hath scanted men in hair he hath given them in wit.

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: ANTIPHOLUS

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Why, but there's many a man hath more hair than wit.

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Not a man of those but he hath the wit to lose his hair.

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: ANTIPHOLUS

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Why, thou didst conclude hairy men plain dealers without wit.

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: The plainer dealer, the sooner lost: yet he loseth

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: it in a kind of jollity.

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: ANTIPHOLUS

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: For what reason?

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: For two; and sound ones too.

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: ANTIPHOLUS

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Nay, not sound, I pray you.

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Sure ones, then.

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: ANTIPHOLUS

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Nay, not sure, in a thing falsing.

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Certain ones then.

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: ANTIPHOLUS

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Name them.

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: The one, to save the money that he spends in

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: trimming; the other, that at dinner they should not

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: drop in his porridge.

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: ANTIPHOLUS

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: You would all this time have proved there is no

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: time for all things.

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Marry, and did, sir; namely, no time to recover hair

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: lost by nature.

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: ANTIPHOLUS

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: But your reason was not substantial, why there is no

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: time to recover.

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Thus I mend it: Time himself is bald and therefore

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: to the world's end will have bald followers.

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: ANTIPHOLUS

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: I knew 'twould be a bald conclusion:

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: But, soft! who wafts us yonder?

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Enter ADRIANA and LUCIANA

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: Ay, ay, Antipholus, look strange and frown:

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: Some other mistress hath thy sweet aspects;

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: I am not Adriana nor thy wife.

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: The time was once when thou unurged wouldst vow

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: That never words were music to thine ear,

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: That never object pleasing in thine eye,

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: That never touch well welcome to thy hand,

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: That never meat sweet-savor'd in thy taste,

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: Unless I spake, or look'd, or touch'd, or carved to thee.

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: How comes it now, my husband, O, how comes it,

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: That thou art thus estranged from thyself?

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: Thyself I call it, being strange to me,

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: That, undividable, incorporate,

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: Am better than thy dear self's better part.

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: Ah, do not tear away thyself from me!

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: For know, my love, as easy mayest thou fall

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: A drop of water in the breaking gulf,

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: And take unmingled that same drop again,

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: Without addition or diminishing,

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: As take from me thyself and not me too.

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: How dearly would it touch me to the quick,

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: Shouldst thou but hear I were licentious

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: And that this body, consecrate to thee,

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: By ruffian lust should be contaminate!

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: Wouldst thou not spit at me and spurn at me

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: And hurl the name of husband in my face

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: And tear the stain'd skin off my harlot-brow

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: And from my false hand cut the wedding-ring

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: And break it with a deep-divorcing vow?

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: I know thou canst; and therefore see thou do it.

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: I am possess'd with an adulterate blot;

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: My blood is mingled with the crime of lust:

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: For if we too be one and thou play false,

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: I do digest the poison of thy flesh,

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: Being strumpeted by thy contagion.

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: Keep then far league and truce with thy true bed;

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: I live unstain'd, thou undishonoured.

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: ANTIPHOLUS

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Plead you to me, fair dame? I know you not:

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: In Ephesus I am but two hours old,

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: As strange unto your town as to your talk;

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Who, every word by all my wit being scann'd,

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Want wit in all one word to understand.

speaker: LUCIANA
text_entry: Fie, brother! how the world is changed with you!

speaker: LUCIANA
text_entry: When were you wont to use my sister thus?

speaker: LUCIANA
text_entry: She sent for you by Dromio home to dinner.

speaker: LUCIANA
text_entry: ANTIPHOLUS

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: By Dromio?

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: By me?

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: By thee; and this thou didst return from him,

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: That he did buffet thee, and, in his blows,

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: Denied my house for his, me for his wife.

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: ANTIPHOLUS

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Did you converse, sir, with this gentlewoman?

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: What is the course and drift of your compact?

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: I, sir? I never saw her till this time.

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: ANTIPHOLUS

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Villain, thou liest; for even her very words

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Didst thou deliver to me on the mart.

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: I never spake with her in all my life.

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: ANTIPHOLUS

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: How can she thus then call us by our names,

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Unless it be by inspiration.

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: How ill agrees it with your gravity

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: To counterfeit thus grossly with your slave,

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: Abetting him to thwart me in my mood!

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: Be it my wrong you are from me exempt,

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: But wrong not that wrong with a more contempt.

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: Come, I will fasten on this sleeve of thine:

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: Thou art an elm, my husband, I a vine,

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: Whose weakness, married to thy stronger state,

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: Makes me with thy strength to communicate:

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: If aught possess thee from me, it is dross,

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: Usurping ivy, brier, or idle moss;

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: Who, all for want of pruning, with intrusion

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: Infect thy sap and live on thy confusion.

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: ANTIPHOLUS

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: To me she speaks; she moves me for her theme:

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: What, was I married to her in my dream?

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Or sleep I now and think I hear all this?

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: What error drives our eyes and ears amiss?

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Until I know this sure uncertainty,

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: I'll entertain the offer'd fallacy.

speaker: LUCIANA
text_entry: Dromio, go bid the servants spread for dinner.

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: O, for my beads! I cross me for a sinner.

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: This is the fairy land: O spite of spites!

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: We talk with goblins, owls and sprites:

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: If we obey them not, this will ensue,

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: They'll suck our breath, or pinch us black and blue.

speaker: LUCIANA
text_entry: Why pratest thou to thyself and answer'st not?

speaker: LUCIANA
text_entry: Dromio, thou drone, thou snail, thou slug, thou sot!

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: I am transformed, master, am I not?

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: ANTIPHOLUS

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: I think thou art in mind, and so am I.

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Nay, master, both in mind and in my shape.

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: ANTIPHOLUS

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Thou hast thine own form.

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: No, I am an ape.

speaker: LUCIANA
text_entry: If thou art changed to aught, 'tis to an ass.

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: 'Tis true; she rides me and I long for grass.

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: 'Tis so, I am an ass; else it could never be

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: But I should know her as well as she knows me.

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: Come, come, no longer will I be a fool,

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: To put the finger in the eye and weep,

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: Whilst man and master laugh my woes to scorn.

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: Come, sir, to dinner. Dromio, keep the gate.

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: Husband, I'll dine above with you to-day

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: And shrive you of a thousand idle pranks.

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: Sirrah, if any ask you for your master,

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: Say he dines forth, and let no creature enter.

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: Come, sister. Dromio, play the porter well.

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: ANTIPHOLUS

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Am I in earth, in heaven, or in hell?

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Sleeping or waking? mad or well-advised?

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Known unto these, and to myself disguised!

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: I'll say as they say and persever so,

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: And in this mist at all adventures go.

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Master, shall I be porter at the gate?

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: Ay; and let none enter, lest I break your pate.

speaker: LUCIANA
text_entry: Come, come, Antipholus, we dine too late.

speaker: LUCIANA
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: LUCIANA
text_entry: ACT III

speaker: LUCIANA
text_entry: SCENE I. Before the house of ANTIPHOLUS of Ephesus.

speaker: LUCIANA
text_entry: Enter ANTIPHOLUS of Ephesus, DROMIO of Ephesus, ANGELO, and BALTHAZAR

speaker: LUCIANA
text_entry: ANTIPHOLUS

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
text_entry: Good Signior Angelo, you must excuse us all;

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
text_entry: My wife is shrewish when I keep not hours:

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
text_entry: Say that I linger'd with you at your shop

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
text_entry: To see the making of her carcanet,

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
text_entry: And that to-morrow you will bring it home.

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
text_entry: But here's a villain that would face me down

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
text_entry: He met me on the mart, and that I beat him,

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
text_entry: And charged him with a thousand marks in gold,

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
text_entry: And that I did deny my wife and house.

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
text_entry: Thou drunkard, thou, what didst thou mean by this?

speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
text_entry: Say what you will, sir, but I know what I know;

speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
text_entry: That you beat me at the mart, I have your hand to show:

speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
text_entry: If the skin were parchment, and the blows you gave were ink,

speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
text_entry: Your own handwriting would tell you what I think.

speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
text_entry: ANTIPHOLUS

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
text_entry: I think thou art an ass.

speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
text_entry: Marry, so it doth appear

speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
text_entry: By the wrongs I suffer and the blows I bear.

speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
text_entry: I should kick, being kick'd; and, being at that pass,

speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
text_entry: You would keep from my heels and beware of an ass.

speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
text_entry: ANTIPHOLUS

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
text_entry: You're sad, Signior Balthazar: pray God our cheer

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
text_entry: May answer my good will and your good welcome here.

speaker: BALTHAZAR
text_entry: I hold your dainties cheap, sir, and your

speaker: BALTHAZAR
text_entry: welcome dear.

speaker: BALTHAZAR
text_entry: ANTIPHOLUS

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
text_entry: O, Signior Balthazar, either at flesh or fish,

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
text_entry: A table full of welcome make scarce one dainty dish.

speaker: BALTHAZAR
text_entry: Good meat, sir, is common; that every churl affords.

speaker: BALTHAZAR
text_entry: ANTIPHOLUS

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
text_entry: And welcome more common; for that's nothing but words.

speaker: BALTHAZAR
text_entry: Small cheer and great welcome makes a merry feast.

speaker: BALTHAZAR
text_entry: ANTIPHOLUS

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
text_entry: Ay, to a niggardly host, and more sparing guest:

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
text_entry: But though my cates be mean, take them in good part;

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
text_entry: Better cheer may you have, but not with better heart.

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
text_entry: But, soft! my door is lock'd. Go bid them let us in.

speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
text_entry: Maud, Bridget, Marian, Cicel, Gillian, Ginn!

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: [Within]  Mome, malt-horse, capon, coxcomb,

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: idiot, patch!

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Either get thee from the door, or sit down at the hatch.

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Dost thou conjure for wenches, that thou call'st

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: for such store,

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: When one is one too many? Go, get thee from the door.

speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
text_entry: What patch is made our porter? My master stays in

speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
text_entry: the street.

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: [Within]  Let him walk from whence he came, lest he

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: catch cold on's feet.

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: ANTIPHOLUS

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
text_entry: Who talks within there? ho, open the door!

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: [Within]  Right, sir; I'll tell you when, an you tell

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: me wherefore.

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: ANTIPHOLUS

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
text_entry: Wherefore? for my dinner: I have not dined to-day.

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: [Within]  Nor to-day here you must not; come again

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: when you may.

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: ANTIPHOLUS

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
text_entry: What art thou that keepest me out from the house I owe?

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: [Within]  The porter for this time, sir, and my name

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: is Dromio.

speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
text_entry: O villain! thou hast stolen both mine office and my name.

speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
text_entry: The one ne'er got me credit, the other mickle blame.

speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
text_entry: If thou hadst been Dromio to-day in my place,

speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
text_entry: Thou wouldst have changed thy face for a name or thy

speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
text_entry: name for an ass.

speaker: LUCE
text_entry: [Within]  What a coil is there, Dromio? who are those

speaker: LUCE
text_entry: at the gate?

speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
text_entry: Let my master in, Luce.

speaker: LUCE
text_entry: [Within]  Faith, no; he comes too late;

speaker: LUCE
text_entry: And so tell your master.

speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
text_entry: O Lord, I must laugh!

speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
text_entry: Have at you with a proverb--Shall I set in my staff?

speaker: LUCE
text_entry: [Within]  Have at you with another; that's--When?

speaker: LUCE
text_entry: can you tell?

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: [Within]  If thy name be call'd Luce--Luce, thou hast

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: answered him well.

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS
text_entry: Do you hear, you minion? you'll let us in, I hope?

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS
text_entry: OF EPHESUS

speaker: LUCE
text_entry: [Within]  I thought to have asked you.

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: [Within]  And you said no.

speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
text_entry: So, come, help: well struck! there was blow for blow.

speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
text_entry: ANTIPHOLUS

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
text_entry: Thou baggage, let me in.

speaker: LUCE
text_entry: [Within]  Can you tell for whose sake?

speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
text_entry: Master, knock the door hard.

speaker: LUCE
text_entry: [Within]  Let him knock till it ache.

speaker: LUCE
text_entry: ANTIPHOLUS

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
text_entry: You'll cry for this, minion, if I beat the door down.

speaker: LUCE
text_entry: [Within]  What needs all that, and a pair of stocks in the town?

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: [Within]  Who is that at the door that keeps all

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: this noise?

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: [Within]  By my troth, your town is troubled with

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: unruly boys.

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: ANTIPHOLUS

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
text_entry: Are you there, wife? you might have come before.

speaker: ADRIANA
text_entry: [Within]  Your wife, sir knave! go get you from the door.

speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
text_entry: If you went in pain, master, this 'knave' would go sore.

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: Here is neither cheer, sir, nor welcome: we would

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: fain have either.

speaker: BALTHAZAR
text_entry: In debating which was best, we shall part with neither.

speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
text_entry: They stand at the door, master; bid them welcome hither.

speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
text_entry: ANTIPHOLUS

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
text_entry: There is something in the wind, that we cannot get in.

speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
text_entry: You would say so, master, if your garments were thin.

speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
text_entry: Your cake there is warm within; you stand here in the cold:

speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
text_entry: It would make a man mad as a buck, to be so bought and sold.

speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
text_entry: ANTIPHOLUS

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
text_entry: Go fetch me something: I'll break ope the gate.

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: [Within]  Break any breaking here, and I'll break your

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: knave's pate.

speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
text_entry: A man may break a word with you, sir, and words are but wind,

speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
text_entry: Ay, and break it in your face, so he break it not behind.

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: [Within]  It seems thou want'st breaking: out upon

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: thee, hind!

speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
text_entry: Here's too much 'out upon thee!' I pray thee,

speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
text_entry: let me in.

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: [Within]  Ay, when fowls have no feathers and fish have no fin.

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: ANTIPHOLUS

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
text_entry: Well, I'll break in: go borrow me a crow.

speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
text_entry: A crow without feather? Master, mean you so?

speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
text_entry: For a fish without a fin, there's a fowl without a feather;

speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
text_entry: If a crow help us in, sirrah, we'll pluck a crow together.

speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
text_entry: ANTIPHOLUS

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
text_entry: Go get thee gone; fetch me an iron crow.

speaker: BALTHAZAR
text_entry: Have patience, sir; O, let it not be so!

speaker: BALTHAZAR
text_entry: Herein you war against your reputation

speaker: BALTHAZAR
text_entry: And draw within the compass of suspect

speaker: BALTHAZAR
text_entry: The unviolated honour of your wife.

speaker: BALTHAZAR
text_entry: Once this,--your long experience of her wisdom,

speaker: BALTHAZAR
text_entry: Her sober virtue, years and modesty,

speaker: BALTHAZAR
text_entry: Plead on her part some cause to you unknown:

speaker: BALTHAZAR
text_entry: And doubt not, sir, but she will well excuse

speaker: BALTHAZAR
text_entry: Why at this time the doors are made against you.

speaker: BALTHAZAR
text_entry: Be ruled by me: depart in patience,

speaker: BALTHAZAR
text_entry: And let us to the Tiger all to dinner,

speaker: BALTHAZAR
text_entry: And about evening come yourself alone

speaker: BALTHAZAR
text_entry: To know the reason of this strange restraint.

speaker: BALTHAZAR
text_entry: If by strong hand you offer to break in

speaker: BALTHAZAR
text_entry: Now in the stirring passage of the day,

speaker: BALTHAZAR
text_entry: A vulgar comment will be made of it,

speaker: BALTHAZAR
text_entry: And that supposed by the common rout

speaker: BALTHAZAR
text_entry: Against your yet ungalled estimation

speaker: BALTHAZAR
text_entry: That may with foul intrusion enter in

speaker: BALTHAZAR
text_entry: And dwell upon your grave when you are dead;

speaker: BALTHAZAR
text_entry: For slander lives upon succession,

speaker: BALTHAZAR
text_entry: For ever housed where it gets possession.

speaker: BALTHAZAR
text_entry: ANTIPHOLUS

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
text_entry: You have prevailed: I will depart in quiet,

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
text_entry: And, in despite of mirth, mean to be merry.

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
text_entry: I know a wench of excellent discourse,

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
text_entry: Pretty and witty; wild, and yet, too, gentle:

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
text_entry: There will we dine. This woman that I mean,

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
text_entry: My wife--but, I protest, without desert--

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
text_entry: Hath oftentimes upbraided me withal:

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
text_entry: To her will we to dinner.

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
text_entry: To Angelo

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
text_entry: Get you home

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
text_entry: And fetch the chain; by this I know 'tis made:

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
text_entry: Bring it, I pray you, to the Porpentine;

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
text_entry: For there's the house: that chain will I bestow--

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
text_entry: Be it for nothing but to spite my wife--

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
text_entry: Upon mine hostess there: good sir, make haste.

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
text_entry: Since mine own doors refuse to entertain me,

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
text_entry: I'll knock elsewhere, to see if they'll disdain me.

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: I'll meet you at that place some hour hence.

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: ANTIPHOLUS

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
text_entry: Do so. This jest shall cost me some expense.

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
text_entry: SCENE II. The same.

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
text_entry: Enter LUCIANA and ANTIPHOLUS of Syracuse

speaker: LUCIANA
text_entry: And may it be that you have quite forgot

speaker: LUCIANA
text_entry: A husband's office? shall, Antipholus.

speaker: LUCIANA
text_entry: Even in the spring of love, thy love-springs rot?

speaker: LUCIANA
text_entry: Shall love, in building, grow so ruinous?

speaker: LUCIANA
text_entry: If you did wed my sister for her wealth,

speaker: LUCIANA
text_entry: Then for her wealth's sake use her with more kindness:

speaker: LUCIANA
text_entry: Or if you like elsewhere, do it by stealth;

speaker: LUCIANA
text_entry: Muffle your false love with some show of blindness:

speaker: LUCIANA
text_entry: Let not my sister read it in your eye;

speaker: LUCIANA
text_entry: Be not thy tongue thy own shame's orator;

speaker: LUCIANA
text_entry: Look sweet, be fair, become disloyalty;

speaker: LUCIANA
text_entry: Apparel vice like virtue's harbinger;

speaker: LUCIANA
text_entry: Bear a fair presence, though your heart be tainted;

speaker: LUCIANA
text_entry: Teach sin the carriage of a holy saint;

speaker: LUCIANA
text_entry: Be secret-false: what need she be acquainted?

speaker: LUCIANA
text_entry: What simple thief brags of his own attaint?

speaker: LUCIANA
text_entry: 'Tis double wrong, to truant with your bed

speaker: LUCIANA
text_entry: And let her read it in thy looks at board:

speaker: LUCIANA
text_entry: Shame hath a bastard fame, well managed;

speaker: LUCIANA
text_entry: Ill d eeds are doubled with an evil word.

speaker: LUCIANA
text_entry: Alas, poor women! make us but believe,

speaker: LUCIANA
text_entry: Being compact of credit, that you love us;

speaker: LUCIANA
text_entry: Though others have the arm, show us the sleeve;

speaker: LUCIANA
text_entry: We in your motion turn and you may move us.

speaker: LUCIANA
text_entry: Then, gentle brother, get you in again;

speaker: LUCIANA
text_entry: Comfort my sister, cheer her, call her wife:

speaker: LUCIANA
text_entry: 'Tis holy sport to be a little vain,

speaker: LUCIANA
text_entry: When the sweet breath of flattery conquers strife.

speaker: LUCIANA
text_entry: ANTIPHOLUS

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Sweet mistress--what your name is else, I know not,

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Nor by what wonder you do hit of mine,--

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Less in your knowledge and your grace you show not

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Than our earth's wonder, more than earth divine.

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Teach me, dear creature, how to think and speak;

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Lay open to my earthy-gross conceit,

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Smother'd in errors, feeble, shallow, weak,

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: The folded meaning of your words' deceit.

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Against my soul's pure truth why labour you

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: To make it wander in an unknown field?

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Are you a god? would you create me new?

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Transform me then, and to your power I'll yield.

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: But if that I am I, then well I know

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Your weeping sister is no wife of mine,

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Nor to her bed no homage do I owe

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Far more, far more to you do I decline.

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: O, train me not, sweet mermaid, with thy note,

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: To drown me in thy sister's flood of tears:

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Sing, siren, for thyself and I will dote:

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Spread o'er the silver waves thy golden hairs,

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: And as a bed I'll take them and there lie,

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: And in that glorious supposition think

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: He gains by death that hath such means to die:

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Let Love, being light, be drowned if she sink!

speaker: LUCIANA
text_entry: What, are you mad, that you do reason so?

speaker: LUCIANA
text_entry: ANTIPHOLUS

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Not mad, but mated; how, I do not know.

speaker: LUCIANA
text_entry: It is a fault that springeth from your eye.

speaker: LUCIANA
text_entry: ANTIPHOLUS

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: For gazing on your beams, fair sun, being by.

speaker: LUCIANA
text_entry: Gaze where you should, and that will clear your sight.

speaker: LUCIANA
text_entry: ANTIPHOLUS

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: As good to wink, sweet love, as look on night.

speaker: LUCIANA
text_entry: Why call you me love? call my sister so.

speaker: LUCIANA
text_entry: ANTIPHOLUS

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Thy sister's sister.

speaker: LUCIANA
text_entry: That's my sister.

speaker: LUCIANA
text_entry: ANTIPHOLUS

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: No;

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: It is thyself, mine own self's better part,

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Mine eye's clear eye, my dear heart's dearer heart,

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: My food, my fortune and my sweet hope's aim,

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: My sole earth's heaven and my heaven's claim.

speaker: LUCIANA
text_entry: All this my sister is, or else should be.

speaker: LUCIANA
text_entry: ANTIPHOLUS

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Call thyself sister, sweet, for I am thee.

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Thee will I love and with thee lead my life:

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Thou hast no husband yet nor I no wife.

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Give me thy hand.

speaker: LUCIANA
text_entry: O, soft, air! hold you still:

speaker: LUCIANA
text_entry: I'll fetch my sister, to get her good will.

speaker: LUCIANA
text_entry: Exit

speaker: LUCIANA
text_entry: Enter DROMIO of Syracuse

speaker: LUCIANA
text_entry: ANTIPHOLUS

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Why, how now, Dromio! where runn'st thou so fast?

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Do you know me, sir? am I Dromio? am I your man?

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: am I myself?

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: ANTIPHOLUS

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Thou art Dromio, thou art my man, thou art thyself.

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: I am an ass, I am a woman's man and besides myself.

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS
text_entry: What woman's man? and how besides thyself? besides thyself?

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Marry, sir, besides myself, I am due to a woman; one

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: that claims me, one that haunts me, one that will have me.

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: ANTIPHOLUS

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: What claim lays she to thee?

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Marry sir, such claim as you would lay to your

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: horse; and she would have me as a beast: not that, I

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: being a beast, she would have me; but that she,

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: being a very beastly creature, lays claim to me.

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: ANTIPHOLUS

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: What is she?

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: A very reverent body; ay, such a one as a man may

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: not speak of without he say 'Sir-reverence.' I have

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: but lean luck in the match, and yet is she a

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: wondrous fat marriage.

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: ANTIPHOLUS

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: How dost thou mean a fat marriage?

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Marry, sir, she's the kitchen wench and all grease;

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: and I know not what use to put her to but to make a

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: lamp of her and run from her by her own light. I

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: warrant, her rags and the tallow in them will burn a

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Poland winter: if she lives till doomsday,

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: she'll burn a week longer than the whole world.

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: ANTIPHOLUS

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: What complexion is she of?

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Swart, like my shoe, but her face nothing half so

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: clean kept: for why, she sweats; a man may go over

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: shoes in the grime of it.

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: ANTIPHOLUS

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: That's a fault that water will mend.

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: No, sir, 'tis in grain; Noah's flood could not do it.

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: ANTIPHOLUS

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: What's her name?

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Nell, sir; but her name and three quarters, that's

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: an ell and three quarters, will not measure her from

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: hip to hip.

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: ANTIPHOLUS

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Then she bears some breadth?

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: No longer from head to foot than from hip to hip:

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: she is spherical, like a globe; I could find out

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: countries in her.

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: ANTIPHOLUS

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: In what part of her body stands Ireland?

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Marry, in her buttocks: I found it out by the bogs.

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: ANTIPHOLUS

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Where Scotland?

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: I found it by the barrenness; hard in the palm of the hand.

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: ANTIPHOLUS

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Where France?

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: In her forehead; armed and reverted, making war

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: against her heir.

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: ANTIPHOLUS

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Where England?

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: I looked for the chalky cliffs, but I could find no

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: whiteness in them; but I guess it stood in her chin,

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: by the salt rheum that ran between France and it.

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: ANTIPHOLUS

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Where Spain?

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Faith, I saw it not; but I felt it hot in her breath.

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: ANTIPHOLUS

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Where America, the Indies?

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Oh, sir, upon her nose all o'er embellished with

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: rubies, carbuncles, sapphires, declining their rich

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: aspect to the hot breath of Spain; who sent whole

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: armadoes of caracks to be ballast at her nose.

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: ANTIPHOLUS

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Where stood Belgia, the Netherlands?

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Oh, sir, I did not look so low. To conclude, this

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: drudge, or diviner, laid claim to me, call'd me

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Dromio; swore I was assured to her; told me what

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: privy marks I had about me, as, the mark of my

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: shoulder, the mole in my neck, the great wart on my

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: left arm, that I amazed ran from her as a witch:

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: And, I think, if my breast had not been made of

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: faith and my heart of steel,

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: She had transform'd me to a curtal dog and made

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: me turn i' the wheel.

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: ANTIPHOLUS

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Go hie thee presently, post to the road:

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: An if the wind blow any way from shore,

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: I will not harbour in this town to-night:

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: If any bark put forth, come to the mart,

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Where I will walk till thou return to me.

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: If every one knows us and we know none,

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: 'Tis time, I think, to trudge, pack and be gone.

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: As from a bear a man would run for life,

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: So fly I from her that would be my wife.

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Exit

speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: ANTIPHOLUS

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: There's none but witches do inhabit here;

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: And therefore 'tis high time that I were hence.

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: She that doth call me husband, even my soul

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Doth for a wife abhor. But her fair sister,

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Possess'd with such a gentle sovereign grace,

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Of such enchanting presence and discourse,

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Hath almost made me traitor to myself:

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: But, lest myself be guilty to self-wrong,

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: I'll stop mine ears against the mermaid's song.

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Enter ANGELO with the chain

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: Master Antipholus,--

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: ANTIPHOLUS

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Ay, that's my name.

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: I know it well, sir, lo, here is the chain.

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: I thought to have ta'en you at the Porpentine:

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: The chain unfinish'd made me stay thus long.

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: ANTIPHOLUS

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: What is your will that I shall do with this?

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: What please yourself, sir: I have made it for you.

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: ANTIPHOLUS

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Made it for me, sir! I bespoke it not.

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: Not once, nor twice, but twenty times you have.

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: Go home with it and please your wife withal;

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: And soon at supper-time I'll visit you

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: And then receive my money for the chain.

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: ANTIPHOLUS

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: I pray you, sir, receive the money now,

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: For fear you ne'er see chain nor money more.

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: You are a merry man, sir: fare you well.

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: Exit

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: ANTIPHOLUS

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: What I should think of this, I cannot tell:

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: But this I think, there's no man is so vain

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: That would refuse so fair an offer'd chain.

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: I see a man here needs not live by shifts,

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: When in the streets he meets such golden gifts.

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: I'll to the mart, and there for Dromio stay

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: If any ship put out, then straight away.

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Exit

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: ACT IV

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: SCENE I. A public place.

speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
text_entry: Enter Second Merchant, ANGELO, and an Officer

speaker: Second Merchant
text_entry: You know since Pentecost the sum is due,

speaker: Second Merchant
text_entry: And since I have not much importuned you;

speaker: Second Merchant
text_entry: Nor now I had not, but that I am bound

speaker: Second Merchant
